Introduction 😛

Welcome to this Probability Study Guide! This guide provides a refresher of fundamental probability concepts and detailed solutions to specific problems. It is structured to first review key ideas (with examples) and then apply them to solve problems step-by-step.

How to use this guide:

  • Begin with the Probability Refresher section to recall important definitions, formulas, and distributions. Work through the examples to reinforce your understanding.
  • Proceed to the Problem Solutions section. For each problem, try to understand the Derivation-based solution (step-by-step reasoning) and then see the Shortcut-based solution (using known formulas or tricks like MGFs).
  • Use the guide actively: pause at examples, attempt to solve them, and compare your approach with the given solution. Happy studying! 🎉

Probability Refresher 📚

Basic Probability Rules

Probability provides a quantitative description of the chances or likelihood of events. Some fundamental rules and properties include:

  • Range of Probability: For any event AAA, 0≤P(A)≤10 \le P(A) \le 10≤P(A)≤1. The probability of the entire sample space Ω\OmegaΩ is 1, and the probability of the impossible event ∅\emptyset∅ is 0.
  • Complement Rule: P(Ac)=1−P(A)P(A^c) = 1 - P(A)P(Ac)=1−P(A), where AcA^cAc is the complement of AAA. (The probability that AAA does not occur.)
  • Addition Rule: For events AAA and BBB, P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B). If AAA and BBB are mutually exclusive (cannot occur together), then P(A∩B)=0P(A \cap B)=0P(A∩B)=0 and P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B)P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B).
  • Conditional Probability: P(A∣B)=P(A∩B)P(B)P(A \mid B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A∩B)​, provided P(B)>0P(B) > 0P(B)>0. This is the probability of AAA given that BBB has occurred.
  • Multiplication Rule: Rearranging the above, P(A∩B)=P(A∣B) P(B)=P(B∣A) P(A)P(A \cap B) = P(A \mid B)\,P(B) = P(B \mid A)\,P(A)P(A∩B)=P(A∣B)P(B)=P(B∣A)P(A). For independent events (no influence on each other), P(A∩B)=P(A) P(B)P(A \cap B) = P(A)\,P(B)P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B).
  • Bayes’ Theorem: P(B∣A)=P(A∣B) P(B)P(A)P(B \mid A) = \frac{P(A \mid B)\,P(B)}{P(A)}P(B∣A)=P(A)P(A∣B)P(B)​. This allows updating probabilities when new information (AAA) is obtained about prior event BBB.

Example: Let P(A)=0.4P(A)=0.4P(A)=0.4, P(B)=0.5P(B)=0.5P(B)=0.5, and P(A∩B)=0.1P(A \cap B)=0.1P(A∩B)=0.1. Then P(A∪B)=0.4+0.5−0.1=0.8P(A \cup B) = 0.4+0.5-0.1 = 0.8P(A∪B)=0.4+0.5−0.1=0.8. The conditional probability P(A∣B)=P(A∩B)/P(B)=0.1/0.5=0.2P(A \mid B) = P(A \cap B)/P(B) = 0.1/0.5 = 0.2P(A∣B)=P(A∩B)/P(B)=0.1/0.5=0.2. Here P(A∩B)P(A \cap B)P(A∩B) is not equal to 0.4×0.5=0.20.4 \times 0.5 = 0.20.4×0.5=0.2, so AAA and BBB are not independent in this example (since 0.1≠0.20.1 \neq 0.20.1=0.2). If they were independent, we would expect P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B)P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B).

Uniform, Exponential, and Beta Distributions

Understanding common probability distributions is essential. Here we review three fundamental continuous distributions:

Uniform Distribution: A continuous random variable XXX is Uniform on an interval [a,b][a, b][a,b], denoted X∼U(a,b)X \sim U(a,b)X∼U(a,b), if its probability density function (pdf) is constant on [a,b][a,b][a,b].

  • PDF: fX(x)=1b−af_X(x) = \frac{1}{b-a}fX​(x)=b−a1​ for a≤x≤ba \le x \le ba≤x≤b (and 0 outside this interval). All intervals of equal length inside [a,b][a,b][a,b] are equally likely.
  • CDF: FX(x)=P(X≤x)=x−a b−a F_X(x) = P(X \le x) = \frac{x-a}{\,b-a\,}FX​(x)=P(X≤x)=b−ax−a​ for a≤x≤ba \le x \le ba≤x≤b. (For x<ax < ax<a, FX(x)=0F_X(x)=0FX​(x)=0; for x≥bx \ge bx≥b, FX(x)=1F_X(x)=1FX​(x)=1.)
  • Mean and Variance: E[X]=a+b2E[X] = \frac{a+b}{2}E[X]=2a+b​, Var(X)=(b−a)212\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{(b-a)^2}{12}Var(X)=12(b−a)2​.
  • Example: If X∼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)X∼U(1,3), then fX(x)=1/2f_X(x)=1/2fX​(x)=1/2 on [1,3][1,3][1,3]. The probability P(X<2)P(X < 2)P(X<2) is 2−13−1=0.5\frac{2-1}{3-1} = 0.53−12−1​=0.5. Likewise P(X>2.5)=3−2.52=0.25P(X>2.5) = \frac{3-2.5}{2} = 0.25P(X>2.5)=23−2.5​=0.25.

Exponential Distribution: The Exponential distribution models waiting times between independent events that occur at a constant average rate. If XXX is Exponential with rate λ>0\lambda>0λ>0, denoted X∼Exp(λ)X \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)X∼Exp(λ), then:

  • PDF: fX(x)=λe−λxf_X(x) = \lambda e^{-\lambda x}fX​(x)=λe−λx for x≥0x \ge 0x≥0 (and 0 for x<0x < 0x<0). It is a decreasing function, meaning smaller values of XXX are more likely.
  • CDF: FX(x)=1−e−λxF_X(x) = 1 - e^{-\lambda x}FX​(x)=1−e−λx for x≥0x \ge 0x≥0. (At x=0x=0x=0, FX(0)=0F_X(0)=0FX​(0)=0; as x→∞x \to \inftyx→∞, FX(x)→1F_X(x) \to 1FX​(x)→1.)
  • Mean and Variance: E[X]=1λE[X] = \frac{1}{\lambda}E[X]=λ1​, Var(X)=1λ2\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{1}{\lambda^2}Var(X)=λ21​.
  • Memoryless Property: P(X>s+t∣X>s)=P(X>t)\displaystyle P(X > s+t \mid X > s) = P(X > t)P(X>s+t∣X>s)=P(X>t). In words, given that one has waited sss time units already, the conditional distribution of the additional waiting time is the same as the original distribution. (The exponential is the only continuous distribution with this property.)
  • Example: If X∼Exp(1)X \sim \text{Exp}(1)X∼Exp(1) (unit rate), then P(X>2)=e−1⋅2=e−2≈0.1353P(X > 2) = e^{-1\cdot 2} = e^{-2} \approx 0.1353P(X>2)=e−1⋅2=e−2≈0.1353. The probability P(X≤3)P(X \le 3)P(X≤3) is 1−e−3≈0.95021 - e^{-3} \approx 0.95021−e−3≈0.9502. Also, if U∼U(0,1)U \sim U(0,1)U∼U(0,1) is uniform on [0,1][0,1][0,1], the transformation Y=−ln⁡(U)Y = -\ln(U)Y=−ln(U) yields Y∼Exp(1)Y \sim \text{Exp}(1)Y∼Exp(1). (We will use this fact later when solving Problem 1.)

Beta Distribution: The Beta distribution is a family of distributions on the interval [0,1][0,1][0,1] with two shape parameters, often used to model probabilities or proportions. We denote X∼Beta(α,β)X \sim \text{Beta}(\alpha,\beta)X∼Beta(α,β) for α,β>0\alpha, \beta > 0α,β>0.

  • PDF: fX(x)=1B(α,β)xα−1(1−x)β−1f_X(x) = \frac{1}{B(\alpha,\beta)} x^{\alpha - 1}(1-x)^{\beta - 1}fX​(x)=B(α,β)1​xα−1(1−x)β−1 for 0≤x≤10 \le x \le 10≤x≤1. Here B(α,β)=Γ(α) Γ(β)Γ(α+β)B(\alpha,\beta) = \frac{\Gamma(\alpha)\,\Gamma(\beta)}{\Gamma(\alpha+\beta)}B(α,β)=Γ(α+β)Γ(α)Γ(β)​ is the Beta function (a normalization constant). The shapes of the density can vary widely: for example, Beta(1,1) is uniform on [0,1], Beta(2,5) is skewed to the left, etc.
  • CDF: There is no simple closed-form CDF except in terms of the incomplete beta function. However, probabilities can be computed via the regularized incomplete beta.
  • Mean and Variance: E[X]=αα+βE[X] = \frac{\alpha}{\alpha + \beta}E[X]=α+βα​, and Var(X)=αβ(α+β)2(α+β+1)\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{\alpha \beta}{(\alpha + \beta)^2 (\alpha + \beta + 1)}Var(X)=(α+β)2(α+β+1)αβ​.
  • Special cases: As noted, Beta(1,1)\text{Beta}(1,1)Beta(1,1) is just U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1) (uniform on [0,1]). If α\alphaα and β\betaβ are integers, the Beta distribution can be seen as the distribution of an order statistic of uniforms (more on this below). For instance, if X1,…,XnX_1,\dots,X_nX1​,…,Xn​ are i.i.d. U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), then the $k$th smallest observation has distribution Beta(k,  n−k+1)\text{Beta}(k,\;n-k+1)Beta(k,n−k+1).
  • Example: X∼Beta(2,2)X \sim \text{Beta}(2,2)X∼Beta(2,2) has pdf fX(x)=6x(1−x)f_X(x) = 6x(1-x)fX​(x)=6x(1−x) for 0<x<10<x<10<x<1, which is symmetric around 0.5. We find E[X]=24=0.5E[X] = \frac{2}{4} = 0.5E[X]=42​=0.5 and Var(X)=2⋅242⋅5=480=0.05\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{2\cdot2}{4^2 \cdot 5} = \frac{4}{80} = 0.05Var(X)=42⋅52⋅2​=804​=0.05.

Joint Distributions and Independence

When dealing with multiple random variables, we describe their behavior using joint distributions:

  • For continuous random variables XXX and YYY, the joint PDF fX,Y(x,y)f_{X,Y}(x,y)fX,Y​(x,y) satisfies P((X,Y)∈A)=∬AfX,Y(x,y) dx dyP((X,Y) \in A) = \iint_A f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dx\,dyP((X,Y)∈A)=∬A​fX,Y​(x,y)dxdy for any region AAA in the plane. The joint PDF must integrate to 1 over the entire support: ∬−∞∞fX,Y(x,y) dx dy=1\iint_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dx\,dy = 1∬−∞∞​fX,Y​(x,y)dxdy=1.
  • Marginal distributions: We can recover the distribution of XXX alone (the marginal fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x)) by integrating out YYY: fX(x)=∫−∞∞fX,Y(x,y) dyf_X(x) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dyfX​(x)=∫−∞∞​fX,Y​(x,y)dy. Similarly fY(y)=∫fX,Y(x,y) dxf_Y(y) = \int f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dxfY​(y)=∫fX,Y​(x,y)dx.
  • Independence: XXX and YYY are independent if and only if their joint PDF factors into the product of the marginals: fX,Y(x,y)=fX(x) fY(y)f_{X,Y}(x,y) = f_X(x)\, f_Y(y)fX,Y​(x,y)=fX​(x)fY​(y) for all (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) in the support. Intuitively, knowing the value of one gives no information about the distribution of the other. Equivalently (for continuous variables), FX,Y(x,y)=FX(x)FY(y)F_{X,Y}(x,y) = F_X(x) F_Y(y)FX,Y​(x,y)=FX​(x)FY​(y). If this factorization does not hold, XXX and YYY are dependent. Dependence often manifests via a restricted support region or a non-factorizable density.

Example (Independent variables): If XXX and YYY are independent U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1) random variables, then fX,Y(x,y)=1⋅1=1f_{X,Y}(x,y) = 1 \cdot 1 = 1fX,Y​(x,y)=1⋅1=1 on the unit square 0≤x≤1, 0≤y≤10\le x\le1,\,0\le y\le10≤x≤1,0≤y≤1. The marginals are each uniform(0,1). Because the support is a rectangle and the density factors, XXX and YYY are independent.

Example (Dependent variables): Suppose (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) is uniformly distributed over a triangular region: S={(x,y):0≤x≤1,  1−x≤y≤1}S = \{(x,y): 0 \le x \le 1,\; 1-x \le y \le 1\}S={(x,y):0≤x≤1,1−x≤y≤1}. This means XXX and YYY can only take values in SSS (for instance, if x=0.2x=0.2x=0.2, then yyy must be between 0.80.80.8 and 111). The joint density can be written as fX,Y(x,y)=kf_{X,Y}(x,y) = kfX,Y​(x,y)=k on SSS (and 0 outside), where kkk is a normalization constant. In this case, the support is not a simple rectangle (it’s a triangle in the unit square), so XXX and YYY are not independent. (We’ll explore this scenario in Problem 2.)

Expectation and Variance

For a random variable XXX:

  • The expectation (or mean) E[X]E[X]E[X] is the long-run average value of XXX. For a continuous XXX, E[X]=∫−∞∞x fX(x) dxE[X] = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x\,f_X(x)\,dxE[X]=∫−∞∞​xfX​(x)dx, provided the integral converges. For a discrete XXX, E[X]=∑xx P(X=x)E[X] = \sum_x x \, P(X=x)E[X]=∑x​xP(X=x).
  • Linearity of expectation: E[aX+bY+c]=a E[X]+b E[Y]+cE[aX + bY + c] = a\,E[X] + b\,E[Y] + cE[aX+bY+c]=aE[X]+bE[Y]+c for any constants a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c. (Importantly, this holds regardless of whether XXX and YYY are independent.)
  • The variance Var(X)=E[(X−E[X])2]=E[X2]−(E[X])2\mathrm{Var}(X) = E[(X - E[X])^2] = E[X^2] - (E[X])^2Var(X)=E[(X−E[X])2]=E[X2]−(E[X])2 measures the spread or dispersion of XXX around its mean. A higher variance means more variability.
  • For a constant aaa and random variable XXX, Var(aX)=a2 Var(X)\mathrm{Var}(aX) = a^2\,\mathrm{Var}(X)Var(aX)=a2Var(X). If XXX and YYY are independent, Var(X+Y)=Var(X)+Var(Y)\mathrm{Var}(X+Y) = \mathrm{Var}(X) + \mathrm{Var}(Y)Var(X+Y)=Var(X)+Var(Y) (variances add for independent sums, since there’s no covariance term).
  • Standard deviation σX=Var(X)\sigma_X = \sqrt{\mathrm{Var}(X)}σX​=Var(X)​ is the square root of variance, in the same units as XXX.

Examples:

  • If X∼U(0,1)X \sim U(0,1)X∼U(0,1), we have E[X]=0.5E[X] = 0.5E[X]=0.5 and Var(X)=1/12≈0.0833\mathrm{Var}(X) = 1/12 \approx 0.0833Var(X)=1/12≈0.0833.
  • If X∼Exp(λ)X \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)X∼Exp(λ), then E[X]=1/λE[X] = 1/\lambdaE[X]=1/λ and Var(X)=1/λ2\mathrm{Var}(X) = 1/\lambda^2Var(X)=1/λ2. For instance, for Exp(1)\text{Exp}(1)Exp(1), E[X]=1E[X]=1E[X]=1 and Var(X)=1\mathrm{Var}(X)=1Var(X)=1.
  • Suppose XXX takes values {0,1,2}\{0,1,2\}{0,1,2} with P(X=0)=0.2P(X=0)=0.2P(X=0)=0.2, P(X=1)=0.5P(X=1)=0.5P(X=1)=0.5, P(X=2)=0.3P(X=2)=0.3P(X=2)=0.3. Then E[X]=0(0.2)+1(0.5)+2(0.3)=1.1E[X] = 0(0.2)+1(0.5)+2(0.3) = 1.1E[X]=0(0.2)+1(0.5)+2(0.3)=1.1. To find Var(X)\mathrm{Var}(X)Var(X), first compute E[X2]=02(0.2)+12(0.5)+22(0.3)=0+0.5+1.2=1.7E[X^2] = 0^2(0.2)+1^2(0.5)+2^2(0.3) = 0 + 0.5 + 1.2 = 1.7E[X2]=02(0.2)+12(0.5)+22(0.3)=0+0.5+1.2=1.7. Thus Var(X)=1.7−(1.1)2=1.7−1.21=0.49\mathrm{Var}(X) = 1.7 - (1.1)^2 = 1.7 - 1.21 = 0.49Var(X)=1.7−(1.1)2=1.7−1.21=0.49.

Moment Generating Functions (MGFs)

The moment generating function of a random variable XXX is defined as MX(t)=E[etX]M_X(t) = E[e^{tX}]MX​(t)=E[etX], for values of ttt in some neighborhood of 0 where this expectation exists. The MGF is a very useful tool because:

  • It generates moments: the $n$th moment E[Xn]E[X^n]E[Xn] can be obtained by differentiating MX(t)M_X(t)MX​(t) nnn times and evaluating at t=0t=0t=0:

    E[Xn]=MX(n)(0)=dndtnMX(t)∣t=0.E[X^n] = M_X^{(n)}(0) = \left.\frac{d^n}{dt^n} M_X(t)\right|_{t=0}. E[Xn]=MX(n)​(0)=dtndn​MX​(t)​t=0​.

    For example, E[X]=MX′(0)E[X] = M_X'(0)E[X]=MX′​(0) and Var(X)=MX′′(0)−[MX′(0)]2\mathrm{Var}(X) = M_X''(0) - [M_X'(0)]^2Var(X)=MX′′​(0)−[MX′​(0)]2.
  • MGFs (if they exist in an open interval containing 000) uniquely determine the distribution. This means if two random variables have the same MGF, they have the same distribution.
  • Sum of independent variables: If XXX and YYY are independent, MX+Y(t)=E[et(X+Y)]=E[etXetY]=E[etX] E[etY]=MX(t) MY(t)M_{X+Y}(t) = E[e^{t(X+Y)}] = E[e^{tX} e^{tY}] = E[e^{tX}]\,E[e^{tY}] = M_X(t)\,M_Y(t)MX+Y​(t)=E[et(X+Y)]=E[etXetY]=E[etX]E[etY]=MX​(t)MY​(t). So the MGF of a sum is the product of MGFs. This property makes it easier to find distributions of sums (e.g. the sum of independent exponentials has an MGF that factors nicely, revealing it is a Gamma distribution).

Examples:

  • For X∼Exp(λ)X \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)X∼Exp(λ), MX(t)=E[etX]=∫0∞etxλe−λx dx=λ∫0∞e−(λ−t)x dxM_X(t) = E[e^{tX}] = \int_0^\infty e^{tx} \lambda e^{-\lambda x}\,dx = \lambda \int_0^\infty e^{-(\lambda - t)x}\,dxMX​(t)=E[etX]=∫0∞​etxλe−λxdx=λ∫0∞​e−(λ−t)xdx (which converges for t<λt < \lambdat<λ). Evaluating the integral gives MX(t)=λλ−tM_X(t) = \frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}MX​(t)=λ−tλ​ for t<λt < \lambdat<λ. We can verify moments: MX′(t)=λ(λ−t)2M_X'(t) = \frac{\lambda}{(\lambda - t)^2}MX′​(t)=(λ−t)2λ​, so MX′(0)=λλ2=1λ=E[X]M_X'(0) = \frac{\lambda}{\lambda^2} = \frac{1}{\lambda} = E[X]MX′​(0)=λ2λ​=λ1​=E[X]. Also MX′′(0)=2λλ3=2λ2M_X''(0) = \frac{2\lambda}{\lambda^3} = \frac{2}{\lambda^2}MX′′​(0)=λ32λ​=λ22​, and indeed Var(X)=MX′′(0)−(MX′(0))2=2λ2−1λ2=1λ2\mathrm{Var}(X) = M_X''(0) - (M_X'(0))^2 = \frac{2}{\lambda^2} - \frac{1}{\lambda^2} = \frac{1}{\lambda^2}Var(X)=MX′′​(0)−(MX′​(0))2=λ22​−λ21​=λ21​.

  • If X1,X2X_1, X_2X1​,X2​ are independent and both ∼Exp(λ)\sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)∼Exp(λ), then MX1+X2(t)=MX1(t) MX2(t)=(λλ−t)(λλ−t)=(λλ−t)2M_{X_1+X_2}(t) = M_{X_1}(t)\,M_{X_2}(t) = \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}\right)\left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}\right) = \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}\right)^2MX1​+X2​​(t)=MX1​​(t)MX2​​(t)=(λ−tλ​)(λ−tλ​)=(λ−tλ​)2. This is the MGF of a Gamma distribution: specifically X1+X2∼Gamma(2,λ)X_1+X_2 \sim \text{Gamma}(2,\lambda)X1​+X2​∼Gamma(2,λ) (which has pdf λ2xe−λx\lambda^2 x e^{-\lambda x}λ2xe−λx). In general, the sum of nnn independent Exp(λ\lambdaλ) is Gamma(n,λ)\text{Gamma}(n,\lambda)Gamma(n,λ).

  • The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) can also be illustrated via MGFs: if X1,…,XnX_1,\ldots,X_nX1​,…,Xn​ are i.i.d. with finite mean μ\muμ and variance σ2\sigma^2σ2, the MGF of the standardized sum ∑i=1nXi−nμσn\frac{\sum_{i=1}^n X_i - n\mu}{\sigma\sqrt{n}}σn​∑i=1n​Xi​−nμ​ tends to et2/2e^{t^2/2}et2/2 as n→∞n\to\inftyn→∞, which is the MGF of a standard Normal N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1). (This is one way to see that the sum tends toward a normal distribution.)

Order Statistics

Given a sample of nnn i.i.d. random variables X1,X2,…,XnX_1, X_2, \dots, X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​, the order statistics are the sample values sorted from smallest to largest. Denote them as Y(1)≤Y(2)≤⋯≤Y(n)Y_{(1)} \le Y_{(2)} \le \cdots \le Y_{(n)}Y(1)​≤Y(2)​≤⋯≤Y(n)​, where Y(1)Y_{(1)}Y(1)​ is the minimum and Y(n)Y_{(n)}Y(n)​ is the maximum. In general, Y(k)Y_{(k)}Y(k)​ is called the $k$th order statistic (the $k$th smallest value). Properties include:

  • Distribution of min and max: It’s straightforward to derive these. Let X(1)=min⁡{X1,…,Xn}X_{(1)} = \min\{X_1,\dots,X_n\}X(1)​=min{X1​,…,Xn​} and X(n)=max⁡{X1,…,Xn}X_{(n)} = \max\{X_1,\dots,X_n\}X(n)​=max{X1​,…,Xn​}.

    • CDF of the minimum: FY(1)(y)=P(min⁡Xi≤y)=1−P(all Xi>y)=1−[1−FX(y)]nF_{Y_{(1)}}(y) = P(\min X_i \le y) = 1 - P(\text{all }X_i > y) = 1 - [1 - F_X(y)]^nFY(1)​​(y)=P(minXi​≤y)=1−P(all Xi​>y)=1−[1−FX​(y)]n. For example, if Xi∼U(0,1)X_i \sim U(0,1)Xi​∼U(0,1), then P(Y(1)>0.2)=[P(Xi>0.2)]n=(0.8)nP(Y_{(1)} > 0.2) = [P(X_i > 0.2)]^n = (0.8)^nP(Y(1)​>0.2)=[P(Xi​>0.2)]n=(0.8)n.
    • CDF of the maximum: FY(n)(y)=P(max⁡Xi≤y)=P(all Xi≤y)=[FX(y)]nF_{Y_{(n)}}(y) = P(\max X_i \le y) = P(\text{all }X_i \le y) = [F_X(y)]^nFY(n)​​(y)=P(maxXi​≤y)=P(all Xi​≤y)=[FX​(y)]n. For i.i.d. U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), P(Y(n)≤0.5)=(0.5)nP(Y_{(n)} \le 0.5) = (0.5)^nP(Y(n)​≤0.5)=(0.5)n.
    • Differentiating yields PDFs: fY(1)(y)=n[1−FX(y)] n−1fX(y)f_{Y_{(1)}}(y) = n[1-F_X(y)]^{\,n-1} f_X(y)fY(1)​​(y)=n[1−FX​(y)]n−1fX​(y) and fY(n)(y)=n[FX(y)] n−1fX(y)f_{Y_{(n)}}(y) = n[F_X(y)]^{\,n-1} f_X(y)fY(n)​​(y)=n[FX​(y)]n−1fX​(y). Intuitively, for the max, this is like: one of the XiX_iXi​ hits approximately yyy (with density fX(y)f_X(y)fX​(y)) and the other n−1n-1n−1 values are all below yyy (each contributing a factor FX(y)F_X(y)FX​(y)). Symmetrically for the min.

  • Distribution of $k$th order statistic (1<k<n1 < k < n1<k<n): In general, Y(k)Y_{(k)}Y(k)​ has PDF:

    fY(k)(y)=n!(k−1)!(n−k)!  [FX(y)] k−1  [1−FX(y)] n−k  fX(y),for y in support.\displaystyle f_{Y_{(k)}}(y) = \frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-k)!}\;[F_X(y)]^{\,k-1}\;[1 - F_X(y)]^{\,n-k}\;f_X(y), \quad \text{for } y \text{ in support.} fY(k)​​(y)=(k−1)!(n−k)!n!​[FX​(y)]k−1[1−FX​(y)]n−kfX​(y),for y in support.

    This formula comes from the fact that out of nnn samples, (k−1)(k-1)(k−1) must fall below yyy, one is at yyy, and (n−k)(n-k)(n−k) above yyy, and there are n!(k−1)!(n−k)!\frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-k)!}(k−1)!(n−k)!n!​ ways to choose which observations those are.

  • Order stats and Beta distribution (for uniform samples): If Xi∼U(0,1)X_i \sim U(0,1)Xi​∼U(0,1), then FX(x)=xF_X(x) = xFX​(x)=x. Plugging into the formula gives fY(k)(y)=n!(k−1)!(n−k)!y k−1(1−y) n−kf_{Y_{(k)}}(y) = \frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-k)!} y^{\,k-1}(1-y)^{\,n-k}fY(k)​​(y)=(k−1)!(n−k)!n!​yk−1(1−y)n−k for 0<y<10<y<10<y<1. This is exactly the Beta(k,  n−k+1)\text{Beta}(k,\; n-k+1)Beta(k,n−k+1) density. So Y(k)∼Beta(k,  n−k+1)Y_{(k)} \sim \text{Beta}(k,\;n-k+1)Y(k)​∼Beta(k,n−k+1) when the sample is uniform(0,1). For example, the median of 5 samples from U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1) (Y(3)Y_{(3)}Y(3)​ for n=5n=5n=5) has distribution Beta(3,3)\text{Beta}(3,3)Beta(3,3), which is symmetric on [0,1].

  • Examples:

    • If we draw n=2n=2n=2 samples from U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), the max Y(2)Y_{(2)}Y(2)​ has CDF P(Y(2)≤y)=y2P(Y_{(2)} \le y) = y^2P(Y(2)​≤y)=y2, so fY(2)(y)=2yf_{Y_{(2)}}(y) = 2yfY(2)​​(y)=2y (for 0<y<10<y<10<y<1). Indeed Y(2)∼Beta(2,1)Y_{(2)} \sim \text{Beta}(2,1)Y(2)​∼Beta(2,1). The min Y(1)Y_{(1)}Y(1)​ has P(Y(1)>y)=(1−y)2P(Y_{(1)} > y) = (1-y)^2P(Y(1)​>y)=(1−y)2, so P(Y(1)≤y)=1−(1−y)2P(Y_{(1)} \le y) = 1-(1-y)^2P(Y(1)​≤y)=1−(1−y)2, and fY(1)(y)=2(1−y)f_{Y_{(1)}}(y) = 2(1-y)fY(1)​​(y)=2(1−y), which is Beta(1,2)\text{Beta}(1,2)Beta(1,2).
    • If Xi∼Exp(λ)X_i \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)Xi​∼Exp(λ), the minimum Y(1)=min⁡iXiY_{(1)} = \min_i X_iY(1)​=mini​Xi​ has an exponential distribution with rate nλn\lambdanλ (faster rate because having nnn opportunities for a small value makes the minimum likely very small). Specifically, P(Y(1)>y)=P(all Xi>y)=e−nλyP(Y_{(1)} > y) = P(\text{all }X_i > y) = e^{-n\lambda y}P(Y(1)​>y)=P(all Xi​>y)=e−nλy, so Y(1)∼Exp(nλ)Y_{(1)} \sim \text{Exp}(n\lambda)Y(1)​∼Exp(nλ). The maximum of exponentials doesn’t have such a simple form, but its distribution can be derived from the general order statistic formula if needed.

With this refresher in mind, let’s tackle some problems to apply these concepts. 🚀

Problem Solutions ✅

Below are detailed solutions to each problem. For each part, we present a Derivation-based solution (step-by-step reasoning using fundamental definitions) and a Shortcut-based solution (leveraging known results or formulas for a quicker solve). Mathematical rigor is maintained in both approaches, but the shortcut highlights how recognizing patterns can save time.

Problem 1 🎲

Given:

  • X∼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)X∼U(1,3) and Y∼U(2,5)Y \sim U(2,5)Y∼U(2,5) are independent continuous random variables.
  • Define W=X YW = X \, YW=XY. (So WWW is the product of XXX and YYY.)

Determine:

  1. The distribution of Z=−ln⁡ ⁣(X−12)Z = -\ln\!\Big(\frac{X - 1}{2}\Big)Z=−ln(2X−1​).
  2. P(W≤8∣Y=4)P(W \le 8 \mid Y = 4)P(W≤8∣Y=4).
  3. (Bonus) The conditional CDF FW∣Y(w∣y)F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y)FW∣Y​(w∣y) (the CDF of WWW given Y=yY=yY=y, in general form).

Part 1: Distribution of Z=−log⁡ ⁣(X−12)Z = -\log\!\big(\frac{X-1}{2}\big)Z=−log(2X−1​)

  • Derivation-based solution: This problem involves a transformation of the random variable XXX. First, note that X−12\frac{X-1}{2}2X−1​ is simply a linear transformation of XXX. Since X∼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)X∼U(1,3), the range of XXX is [1,3][1,3][1,3]. Thus the range of U:=X−12U := \frac{X-1}{2}U:=2X−1​ is [0,1][0,1][0,1] (because when X=1X=1X=1, (X−1)/2=0(X-1)/2 = 0(X−1)/2=0, and when X=3X=3X=3, (X−1)/2=1(X-1)/2 = 1(X−1)/2=1). In fact, UUU is uniform on [0,1][0,1][0,1]: one can see this by finding UUU’s CDF for 0≤u≤10 \le u \le 10≤u≤1:

    P(U≤u)=P ⁣(X−12≤u)=P(X≤2u+1).P(U \le u) = P\!\Big(\frac{X-1}{2} \le u\Big) = P(X \le 2u + 1). P(U≤u)=P(2X−1​≤u)=P(X≤2u+1).

    Since XXX is uniform on [1,3][1,3][1,3], P(X≤2u+1)=(2u+1)−13−1=2u2=uP(X \le 2u+1) = \frac{(2u+1) - 1}{3-1} = \frac{2u}{2} = uP(X≤2u+1)=3−1(2u+1)−1​=22u​=u. Thus FU(u)=uF_U(u) = uFU​(u)=u for 0≤u≤10 \le u \le 10≤u≤1, which confirms U∼U(0,1)U \sim U(0,1)U∼U(0,1). (This result could also be obtained by noting the linear transformation of a uniform yields a uniform: if X∼U(a,b)X \sim U(a,b)X∼U(a,b) then X−a b−a ∼U(0,1)\frac{X-a}{\,b-a\,} \sim U(0,1)b−aX−a​∼U(0,1).)

    Now Z=−ln⁡(U)Z = -\ln(U)Z=−ln(U) where U∼U(0,1)U \sim U(0,1)U∼U(0,1). This is a classic transformation: If UUU is uniform on (0,1)(0,1)(0,1), then Z=−ln⁡UZ = -\ln UZ=−lnU follows an Exponential(1) distribution. Let’s derive this formally by finding the CDF of ZZZ: for z≥0z \ge 0z≥0,

    FZ(z)=P(Z≤z)=P(−ln⁡U≤z)=P(ln⁡U≥−z)(multiplying by -1 flips inequality)=P(U≥e−z)=1−P(U<e−z)=1−FU(e−z).\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} F_Z(z) &= P(Z \le z) = P(-\ln U \le z) \ &= P(\ln U \ge -z) \quad\text{(multiplying by -1 flips inequality)} \ &= P(U \ge e^{-z}) \ &= 1 - P(U < e^{-z}) \ &= 1 - F_U(e^{-z}). \end{aligned} ]
    FZ​(z)​=P(Z≤z)=P(−lnU≤z)=P(lnU≥−z)(multiplying by -1 flips inequality)=P(U≥e−z)=1−P(U<e−z)=1−FU​(e−z).​

    For 0<e−z≤10 < e^{-z} \le 10<e−z≤1, we have FU(e−z)=e−zF_U(e^{-z}) = e^{-z}FU​(e−z)=e−z (since UUU is uniform on [0,1][0,1][0,1]). Thus

    FZ(z)=1−e−z,z≥0.F_Z(z) = 1 - e^{-z}, \quad z \ge 0. FZ​(z)=1−e−z,z≥0.

    This is exactly the CDF of an Exp(1)\text{Exp}(1)Exp(1) distribution. (For z<0z < 0z<0, FZ(z)=0F_Z(z)=0FZ​(z)=0 since Z≥0Z \ge 0Z≥0 always.) Differentiating, the PDF of ZZZ is fZ(z)=e−zf_Z(z) = e^{-z}fZ​(z)=e−z for z≥0z \ge 0z≥0. Therefore, ZZZ is Exponential with rate 111.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Recognize that X−12∼U(0,1)\frac{X-1}{2} \sim U(0,1)2X−1​∼U(0,1). There’s a known fact: if U∼Uniform(0,1)U \sim \text{Uniform}(0,1)U∼Uniform(0,1), then −ln⁡(U)∼Exponential(1)-\ln(U) \sim \text{Exponential}(1)−ln(U)∼Exponential(1). This result comes from the fundamental connection between the uniform and exponential distributions (often used in simulation: to generate an Exp(λ\lambdaλ) one can take −1λln⁡U-\frac{1}{\lambda}\ln U−λ1​lnU). Using this directly, we conclude Z=−ln⁡ ⁣(X−12)∼Exp(1)Z = -\ln\!\big(\frac{X-1}{2}\big) \sim \text{Exp}(1)Z=−ln(2X−1​)∼Exp(1). In other words, ZZZ has an exponential distribution with mean 1 (rate 111).

Part 2: P(W≤8∣Y=4)P(W \le 8 \mid Y = 4)P(W≤8∣Y=4)

  • Derivation-based solution: Here we are asked for a conditional probability given Y=4Y=4Y=4. When conditioning on Y=4Y=4Y=4, we treat Y=4Y=4Y=4 as known information. Because XXX and YYY are independent, the conditional distribution of XXX given Y=4Y=4Y=4 is just the distribution of XXX itself (independence implies XXX is unaffected by knowing YYY). So XXX remains U(1,3)U(1,3)U(1,3). Now W=X⋅YW = X \cdot YW=X⋅Y. If Y=4Y=4Y=4, then W=4XW = 4XW=4X. Thus:

    P(W≤8∣Y=4)=P(4X≤8∣Y=4)=P(X≤2∣Y=4).P(W \le 8 \mid Y=4) = P(4X \le 8 \mid Y=4) = P(X \le 2 \mid Y=4). P(W≤8∣Y=4)=P(4X≤8∣Y=4)=P(X≤2∣Y=4).

    (We divided both sides of the inequality by 4; since 4 is positive this preserves the inequality direction.) Now P(X≤2∣Y=4)=P(X≤2)P(X \le 2 \mid Y=4) = P(X \le 2)P(X≤2∣Y=4)=P(X≤2) because XXX is independent of YYY. Since X∼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)X∼U(1,3), we can compute this probability easily:

    P(X≤2)=2−1 3−1 =12=0.5.P(X \le 2) = \frac{2 - 1}{\,3 - 1\,} = \frac{1}{2} = 0.5. P(X≤2)=3−12−1​=21​=0.5.

    Thus, the answer is 0.5\displaystyle 0.50.5.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Reasoning directly, when Y=4Y=4Y=4, the random variable WWW becomes 4X4X4X. The condition W≤8W \le 8W≤8 then simplifies to X≤2X \le 2X≤2. We know XXX is uniform on [1,3][1,3][1,3], so the proportion of the interval [1,3][1,3][1,3] where X≤2X \le 2X≤2 is exactly half of it (from 1 to 2 is half of the length from 1 to 3). Therefore, without doing any integration, we can see P(X≤2)=0.5P(X \le 2) = 0.5P(X≤2)=0.5. The conditional probability P(W≤8∣Y=4)P(W \le 8 \mid Y=4)P(W≤8∣Y=4) is the same 0.50.50.5.

Part 3: Conditional CDF FW∣Y(w∣y)F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y)FW∣Y​(w∣y) (Bonus)

  • Derivation-based solution: We want the distribution of WWW given an arbitrary Y=yY=yY=y. Treat yyy as a constant in the analysis. Given Y=yY=yY=y, we have W=X⋅yW = X \cdot yW=X⋅y. This is a linear scaling of XXX by the factor yyy. Since X∼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)X∼U(1,3) (independent of YYY), conditional on Y=yY=yY=y, XXX is still uniform (1,3)(1,3)(1,3). Therefore:

    • The minimum possible value of WWW (given Y=yY=yY=y) is when XXX takes its minimum 1, yielding Wmin⁡=1⋅y=yW_{\min} = 1 \cdot y = yWmin​=1⋅y=y.
    • The maximum possible value of WWW is when X=3X=3X=3, giving Wmax⁡=3yW_{\max} = 3yWmax​=3y.

    Because XXX given Y=yY=yY=y is uniform on [1,3][1,3][1,3], the transformed variable W=y⋅XW = y \cdot XW=y⋅X will be uniform on [y, 3y][y,\,3y][y,3y]. (For a fixed yyy, this is just a stretch of the interval by factor yyy.) We can formally derive the conditional CDF by: for www in the range [y,3y][y,3y][y,3y],

    FW∣Y(w∣y)=P(W≤w∣Y=y)=P(yX≤w∣Y=y).F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y) = P(W \le w \mid Y=y) = P(y X \le w \mid Y=y). FW∣Y​(w∣y)=P(W≤w∣Y=y)=P(yX≤w∣Y=y).

    Since y>0y>0y>0 (in fact y∈[2,5]y\in[2,5]y∈[2,5] given YYY's support), divide by yyy:

    P(X≤w/y∣Y=y)=w/y−13−1,P(X \le w/y \mid Y=y) = \frac{w/y - 1}{3 - 1}, P(X≤w/y∣Y=y)=3−1w/y−1​,

    as long as 1≤w/y≤31 \le w/y \le 31≤w/y≤3. Simplifying w/y−12\frac{w/y - 1}{2}2w/y−1​, we get:

    FW∣Y(w∣y)=w−y2y,for y≤w≤3y.F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y) = \frac{w - y}{2y}, \quad \text{for } y \le w \le 3y. FW∣Y​(w∣y)=2yw−y​,for y≤w≤3y.

    We should also specify the CDF outside this range: FW∣Y(w∣y)=0F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y) = 0FW∣Y​(w∣y)=0 for w<yw < yw<y (it can’t be less than yyy), and FW∣Y(w∣y)=1F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y) = 1FW∣Y​(w∣y)=1 for w≥3yw \ge 3yw≥3y (it can’t exceed 3y3y3y). Summarizing:

    FW∣Y(w∣y)={0,w<y, w−y 2y,y≤w≤3y,1,w>3y ,F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y) = \begin{cases} 0, & w < y, \\[6pt] \displaystyle \frac{\,w - y\,}{2y}, & y \le w \le 3y, \\[1ex] 1, & w > 3y~, \end{cases} FW∣Y​(w∣y)=⎩⎨⎧​0,2yw−y​,1,​w<y,y≤w≤3y,w>3y ,​

    for yyy in the support of YYY (here 2≤y≤52 \le y \le 52≤y≤5). This is the CDF of a Uniform(y,3y)\text{Uniform}(y, 3y)Uniform(y,3y) distribution, which is exactly what W∣Y=yW|Y=yW∣Y=y is.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Using knowledge of linear transformations: if XXX is uniform on [1,3][1,3][1,3], then for a fixed yyy, W=yXW = yXW=yX is uniform on [y⋅1,  y⋅3]=[y,3y][y \cdot 1,\; y \cdot 3] = [y,3y][y⋅1,y⋅3]=[y,3y]. We can write this result directly. Thus the conditional density is fW∣Y=y(w)=13y−y=12yf_{W|Y=y}(w) = \frac{1}{3y - y} = \frac{1}{2y}fW∣Y=y​(w)=3y−y1​=2y1​ for w∈[y,3y]w \in [y,3y]w∈[y,3y]. Integrating to get the CDF gives FW∣Y(w∣y)=w−y2yF_{W|Y}(w|y) = \frac{w-y}{2y}FW∣Y​(w∣y)=2yw−y​ (for www between yyy and 3y3y3y), which matches the derived answer above. Recognizing the uniform scaling saved time in deriving the piecewise expression.

Problem 2 📉

Given:

  • Support set SXY={(x,y)∈R2:0≤x≤1,  1−x≤y≤1}S_{XY} = \{(x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 : 0 \le x \le 1,\; 1-x \le y \le 1\}SXY​={(x,y)∈R2:0≤x≤1,1−x≤y≤1}. (This is a triangular region in the xxx-yyy plane.)
  • Joint density function f(x,y)=k⋅1{(x,y)∈SXY}f(x,y) = k \cdot \mathbf{1}\{(x,y) \in S_{XY}\}f(x,y)=k⋅1{(x,y)∈SXY​}, where k>0k>0k>0 is a constant and 1{⋅}\mathbf{1}\{\cdot\}1{⋅} is the indicator function. In other words, (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) is uniformly distributed over the region SXYS_{XY}SXY​, with kkk as the normalization constant.

Determine:

  1. The value of kkk.
  2. P(Y> 1/3)P(Y > \,1/3)P(Y>1/3).
  3. P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3)P(X \ge 1/2 \mid Y > 1/3)P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3).
  4. (Bonus) P(X+Y>1/2)P(X + Y > 1/2)P(X+Y>1/2).

First, let’s understand the geometry of the support SXYS_{XY}SXY​. The conditions 0≤x≤10 \le x \le 10≤x≤1 and 1−x≤y≤11-x \le y \le 11−x≤y≤1 describe a triangle in the unit square. When x=0x=0x=0, yyy ranges from 111 to 111 (so the point (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) is included). When x=1x=1x=1, yyy ranges from 000 to 111 (so (1,0)(1,0)(1,0) up to (1,1)(1,1)(1,1) are included). The lower boundary of the region is given by y=1−xy = 1 - xy=1−x (a line from (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) to (1,0)(1,0)(1,0)). The region is the set of points above that line (including the line), up to y=1y=1y=1. So it's a right triangle with vertices at (0,1)(0,1)(0,1), (1,0)(1,0)(1,0), and (1,1)(1,1)(1,1).

Because (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) is uniformly distributed over this triangle, the joint density is constant (=k=k=k) on the triangle and zero outside.

Part 1: Find kkk

  • Derivation-based solution: The constant kkk is determined by the requirement that the total probability over the support equals 1. Thus, we must have

    ∬SXYk dx dy=1.\iint_{S_{XY}} k \,dx\,dy = 1. ∬SXY​​kdxdy=1.

    Geometrically, ∬SXYk dx dy=k⋅Area(SXY)\iint_{S_{XY}} k\,dx\,dy = k \cdot \text{Area}(S_{XY})∬SXY​​kdxdy=k⋅Area(SXY​). So k=1Area(SXY)k = \frac{1}{\text{Area}(S_{XY})}k=Area(SXY​)1​. The region SXYS_{XY}SXY​ is a right triangle. We can compute its area by noting the base and height are both 1 (the line from (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) to (1,0)(1,0)(1,0) has length 2\sqrt{2}2​, but easier: it spans 1 in the xxx-direction and 1 in the yyy-direction). The area of a right triangle with legs of length 1 is 12(1)(1)=12\frac{1}{2}(1)(1) = \frac{1}{2}21​(1)(1)=21​.
    Therefore, k=11/2=2k = \frac{1}{1/2} = 2k=1/21​=2. To be thorough, we can integrate using calculus:

    ∬SXYk dx dy=∫x=01∫y= 1−x1k dy dx=k∫01[ 1−(1−x) ] dx=k∫01x dx=k⋅12.\iint_{S_{XY}} k\,dx\,dy = \int_{x=0}^1 \int_{y=\,1-x}^{1} k \,dy\,dx = k \int_{0}^{1} [\,1 - (1-x)\,]\,dx = k \int_{0}^{1} x\,dx = k \cdot \frac{1}{2}. ∬SXY​​kdxdy=∫x=01​∫y=1−x1​kdydx=k∫01​[1−(1−x)]dx=k∫01​xdx=k⋅21​.

    Setting this equal to 1 gives k⋅12=1k \cdot \frac{1}{2} = 1k⋅21​=1, so k=2k = 2k=2.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Recognize that SXYS_{XY}SXY​ is half of the unit square (the triangle above the diagonal line x+y=1x+y=1x+y=1 within [0,1]2[0,1]^2[0,1]2). The area of the unit square is 1, and since it’s split by the line x+y=1x+y=1x+y=1 into two equal triangles, the area of SXYS_{XY}SXY​ is 0.50.50.5. For a uniform distribution over this area, the density must be the reciprocal of the area. Thus k=1/(0.5)=2k = 1/(0.5) = 2k=1/(0.5)=2.

Part 2: P(Y> 1/3)P(Y > \,1/3)P(Y>1/3)

  • Derivation-based solution: This is the probability that YYY exceeds 1/31/31/3. We need to integrate the joint density over all (x,y)∈SXY(x,y) \in S_{XY}(x,y)∈SXY​ such that y>1/3y > 1/3y>1/3. In notation:

    P(Y>1/3)=∬{(x,y)∈SXY: y>1/3}f(x,y) dx dy.P(Y > 1/3) = \iint_{\{(x,y)\in S_{XY}:~y > 1/3\}} f(x,y)\,dx\,dy. P(Y>1/3)=∬{(x,y)∈SXY​: y>1/3}​f(x,y)dxdy.

    We know f(x,y)=2f(x,y) = 2f(x,y)=2 on SXYS_{XY}SXY​. So we integrate 222 over the subset of the triangle where y>1/3y > 1/3y>1/3. It may be easier to integrate with respect to xxx first: consider xxx from 0 to 1, and for each xxx, determine the range of yyy such that y>1/3y > 1/3y>1/3 and (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) is in SXYS_{XY}SXY​. The condition for (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) to be in SXYS_{XY}SXY​ is y≥1−xy \ge 1-xy≥1−x. We also need y>1/3y > 1/3y>1/3. Therefore, for a given xxx, the lower limit for yyy in the integration will be max⁡(1−x,  1/3)\max(1-x,\;1/3)max(1−x,1/3). The upper limit is always 1 (the top of the region). So:

    P(Y>1/3)=∫x=01∫y=max⁡(1−x,  1/3) 12 dy dx.P(Y > 1/3) = \int_{x=0}^{1} \int_{y=\max(1-x,\;1/3)}^{\,1} 2 \,dy\,dx. P(Y>1/3)=∫x=01​∫y=max(1−x,1/3)1​2dydx.

    We should break this integral into cases for xxx where 1−x1-x1−x vs 1/31/31/3 is the active lower bound (i.e. which one is larger). Solve 1−x=1/31-x = 1/31−x=1/3 to find the switching point: that gives x=2/3x = 2/3x=2/3. So:

    • For 0≤x≤2/30 \le x \le 2/30≤x≤2/3, we have 1−x≥1/31-x \ge 1/31−x≥1/3 (because if x=2/3x=2/3x=2/3, 1−x=1/31-x = 1/31−x=1/3, and for smaller xxx, 1−x1-x1−x is larger). Thus max⁡(1−x,1/3)=1−x\max(1-x, 1/3) = 1-xmax(1−x,1/3)=1−x. In this range, the integration over yyy goes from y=1−xy=1-xy=1−x to y=1y=1y=1.
    • For 2/3<x≤12/3 < x \le 12/3<x≤1, we have 1−x<1/31-x < 1/31−x<1/3. Thus max⁡(1−x,1/3)=1/3\max(1-x, 1/3) = 1/3max(1−x,1/3)=1/3. In this range, the integration over yyy is from y=1/3y=1/3y=1/3 to y=1y=1y=1.

    Now compute in two parts:

    P(Y>1/3)=2[∫x=02/3∫y= 1−x1dy dx  +  ∫x=2/31∫y= 1/31dy dx]=2[∫02/3(1−(1−x)) dx  +  ∫2/31(1−1/3) dx]=2[∫02/3x dx  +  ∫2/3123 dx]=2[x22∣02/3  +  23(1−2/3)]=2[(2/3)22  +  23⋅13]=2[418+29]=2[29+29]=2⋅49=89.\begin{aligned} P(Y > 1/3) &= 2\left[\int_{x=0}^{2/3} \int_{y=\,1-x}^{1} dy\,dx \;+\; \int_{x=2/3}^{1} \int_{y=\,1/3}^{1} dy\,dx \right] \\ &= 2\left[\int_{0}^{2/3} (1 - (1-x))\,dx \;+\; \int_{2/3}^{1} (1 - 1/3)\,dx \right] \\ &= 2\left[\int_{0}^{2/3} x\,dx \;+\; \int_{2/3}^{1} \frac{2}{3}\,dx \right] \\ &= 2\left[ \left.\frac{x^2}{2}\right|_{0}^{2/3} \;+\; \frac{2}{3} (1 - 2/3) \right] \\ &= 2\left[ \frac{(2/3)^2}{2} \;+\; \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{3} \right] \\ &= 2\left[ \frac{4}{18} + \frac{2}{9} \right] = 2\left[ \frac{2}{9} + \frac{2}{9} \right] \\ &= 2 \cdot \frac{4}{9} = \frac{8}{9}. \end{aligned}P(Y>1/3)​=2[∫x=02/3​∫y=1−x1​dydx+∫x=2/31​∫y=1/31​dydx]=2[∫02/3​(1−(1−x))dx+∫2/31​(1−1/3)dx]=2[∫02/3​xdx+∫2/31​32​dx]=2[2x2​​02/3​+32​(1−2/3)]=2[2(2/3)2​+32​⋅31​]=2[184​+92​]=2[92​+92​]=2⋅94​=98​.​

    So P(Y>1/3)=89≈0.888…P(Y > 1/3) = \frac{8}{9} \approx 0.888\ldotsP(Y>1/3)=98​≈0.888….

    To double-check, we can also find the marginal distribution of YYY and integrate from 1/31/31/3 to 1. The marginal density fY(y)f_Y(y)fY​(y) can be obtained by integrating out xxx: for a fixed yyy, xxx ranges from 000 to 111 subject to the point (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) being in SXYS_{XY}SXY​. The condition 1−x≤y≤11-x \le y \le 11−x≤y≤1 implies x≤1−yx \le 1 - yx≤1−y. Also 0≤x≤10 \le x \le 10≤x≤1. So for a given yyy in [0,1][0,1][0,1], xxx goes from 000 up to 1−y1-y1−y. Thus fY(y)=∫x=0 1−y2 dx=2(1−y)f_Y(y) = \int_{x=0}^{\,1-y} 2\,dx = 2(1-y)fY​(y)=∫x=01−y​2dx=2(1−y), for 0≤y≤10 \le y \le 10≤y≤1. (This is the equation of a line from fY(0)=2f_Y(0)=2fY​(0)=2 down to fY(1)=0f_Y(1)=0fY​(1)=0, which makes sense for a triangular density’s marginal.) Now P(Y>1/3)=∫y=1/312(1−y) dy=2(y−y22)∣1/31=2[(1−12)−(13−118)]=2[12−13+118]=2[9−6+118]=2[418]=89.P(Y > 1/3) = \int_{y=1/3}^{1} 2(1-y)\,dy = \left.2\left(y - \frac{y^2}{2}\right)\right|_{1/3}^{1} = 2\left[(1 - \tfrac{1}{2}) - \left(\tfrac{1}{3} - \tfrac{1}{18}\right)\right] = 2\left[\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{18}\right] = 2\left[\frac{9 - 6 + 1}{18}\right] = 2\left[\frac{4}{18}\right] = \frac{8}{9}.P(Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31​2(1−y)dy=2(y−2y2​)​1/31​=2[(1−21​)−(31​−181​)]=2[21​−31​+181​]=2[189−6+1​]=2[184​]=98​.
    Great, it matches.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Using the marginal density we found quickly: YYY’s marginal on [0,1][0,1][0,1] is fY(y)=2(1−y)f_Y(y) = 2(1-y)fY​(y)=2(1−y) (a triangular distribution that increases linearly toward y=0y=0y=0). This can be reasoned without full integration by recognizing that the joint is uniform on a triangle – the distribution of YYY will have a density proportional to the length of the horizontal slice at yyy. At a height yyy, the horizontal slice runs from x=0x=0x=0 to x=1−yx=1-yx=1−y (from the line x=0x=0x=0 to the line x=1−yx=1-yx=1−y rearranged from y=1−xy=1-xy=1−x), so the length is 1−y1-y1−y. Uniform density implies fY(y)∝(1−y)f_Y(y) \propto (1-y)fY​(y)∝(1−y), and the constant can be found by ∫012(1−y)dy=1\int_0^1 2(1-y)dy=1∫01​2(1−y)dy=1. Now simply integrate the tail from 1/31/31/3 to 111:

    P(Y>1/3)=∫y=1/312(1−y)dy=[2(y−y22)]y=1/31=2[(1−12)−(13−118)]=89.P(Y > 1/3) = \int_{y=1/3}^{1} 2(1-y)dy = \left[2\left(y - \frac{y^2}{2}\right)\right]_{y=1/3}^{1} = 2\left[(1 - \tfrac{1}{2}) - (\tfrac{1}{3} - \tfrac{1}{18})\right] = \frac{8}{9}. P(Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31​2(1−y)dy=[2(y−2y2​)]y=1/31​=2[(1−21​)−(31​−181​)]=98​.

    Alternatively, one could notice that P(Y>1/3)=1−P(Y≤1/3)P(Y > 1/3) = 1 - P(Y \le 1/3)P(Y>1/3)=1−P(Y≤1/3). Now P(Y≤1/3)P(Y \le 1/3)P(Y≤1/3) is the area of the part of the triangle with y≤1/3y \le 1/3y≤1/3. Since the triangle extends from y=0y=0y=0 to y=1y=1y=1, we might find the fraction of area with y≤1/3y \le 1/3y≤1/3. That region itself is a smaller triangle with vertices at (1,0)(1,0)(1,0), (1,1/3)(1,1/3)(1,1/3), and (2/3,1/3)(2/3,1/3)(2/3,1/3) (check: at y=1/3y=1/3y=1/3, xxx goes from x=1−y=2/3x=1-y=2/3x=1−y=2/3 to x=1x=1x=1). The base of that smaller triangle is along y=1/3y=1/3y=1/3 from x=2/3x=2/3x=2/3 to x=1x=1x=1 (length =1/3=1/3=1/3) and the height is 1/31/31/3 (from y=0y=0y=0 to y=1/3y=1/3y=1/3 at x=1x=1x=1). Its area is 12⋅13⋅13=118\frac{1}{2}\cdot \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{3} = \frac{1}{18}21​⋅31​⋅31​=181​. Thus P(Y≤1/3)=P(Y \le 1/3) =P(Y≤1/3)= (area)×k=118⋅2=19\times k = \frac{1}{18} \cdot 2 = \frac{1}{9}×k=181​⋅2=91​. So P(Y>1/3)=1−1/9=8/9P(Y>1/3) = 1 - 1/9 = 8/9P(Y>1/3)=1−1/9=8/9.

Part 3: P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3)P(X \ge 1/2 \mid Y > 1/3)P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3)

  • Derivation-based solution: This conditional probability can be computed as P(X≥1/2 and Y>1/3)P(Y>1/3)\displaystyle \frac{P(X \ge 1/2 \text{ and } Y > 1/3)}{P(Y > 1/3)}P(Y>1/3)P(X≥1/2 and Y>1/3)​. We already have P(Y>1/3)=8/9P(Y > 1/3) = 8/9P(Y>1/3)=8/9 from Part 2. Now we need the joint probability P(X≥1/2,  Y>1/3)P(X \ge 1/2,\; Y > 1/3)P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3). We integrate the joint density over the subset of SXYS_{XY}SXY​ where x∈[1/2,1]x \in [1/2,1]x∈[1/2,1] and y>1/3y > 1/3y>1/3:

    P(X≥1/2, Y>1/3)=∫x=1/21∫y=max⁡(1−x, 1/3) 12 dy dx.P(X \ge 1/2,\, Y > 1/3) = \int_{x=1/2}^{1} \int_{y=\max(1-x,\,1/3)}^{\,1} 2\,dy\,dx. P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3)=∫x=1/21​∫y=max(1−x,1/3)1​2dydx.

    We must be careful again about the lower limit of yyy for a given xxx. For xxx in [1/2,1][1/2,1][1/2,1], 1−x1-x1−x ranges from 1/21/21/2 down to 000. Compare 1−x1-x1−x with 1/31/31/3:

    • If xxx is small (near 1/21/21/2), 1−x1-x1−x might be ≥1/3\ge 1/3≥1/3.
    • If xxx is large (near 1), 1−x1-x1−x might be <1/3< 1/3<1/3. The boundary between these cases is where 1−x=1/31-x = 1/31−x=1/3, i.e. x=2/3x = 2/3x=2/3 (same as before). So split at x=2/3x=2/3x=2/3:
      For x∈[1/2, 2/3]x \in [1/2,\,2/3]x∈[1/2,2/3]: 1−x≥1/31-x \ge 1/31−x≥1/3, so max⁡(1−x,1/3)=1−x\max(1-x,1/3) = 1-xmax(1−x,1/3)=1−x.
      For x∈[2/3, 1]x \in [2/3,\,1]x∈[2/3,1]: 1−x≤1/31-x \le 1/31−x≤1/3, so max⁡(1−x,1/3)=1/3\max(1-x,1/3) = 1/3max(1−x,1/3)=1/3.

    Now integrate in two pieces:

    P(X≥1/2, Y>1/3)=2[∫x=1/22/3∫y= 1−x1dy dx+∫x=2/31∫y= 1/31dy dx]=2[∫1/22/3(1−(1−x)) dx+∫2/31(1−1/3) dx]=2[∫1/22/3x dx+∫2/3123 dx]=2[x22∣1/22/3+23(1−2/3)]=2[(2/3)2−(1/2)22+23⋅13]=2[49−142+29]=2[1636−9362+29]=2[736+29]=2[736+836]=2⋅1536=1518=56.\begin{aligned} P(X \ge 1/2,\, Y > 1/3) &= 2\left[\int_{x=1/2}^{2/3} \int_{y=\,1-x}^{1} dy\,dx + \int_{x=2/3}^{1} \int_{y=\,1/3}^{1} dy\,dx \right] \\ &= 2\left[\int_{1/2}^{2/3} (1 - (1-x))\,dx + \int_{2/3}^{1} (1 - 1/3)\,dx \right] \\ &= 2\left[\int_{1/2}^{2/3} x\,dx + \int_{2/3}^{1} \frac{2}{3}\,dx \right] \\ &= 2\left[\left.\frac{x^2}{2}\right|_{1/2}^{2/3} + \frac{2}{3}(1 - 2/3) \right] \\ &= 2\left[\frac{(2/3)^2 - (1/2)^2}{2} + \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{3} \right] \\ &= 2\left[\frac{\frac{4}{9} - \frac{1}{4}}{2} + \frac{2}{9} \right] \\ &= 2\left[\frac{\frac{16}{36} - \frac{9}{36}}{2} + \frac{2}{9} \right] \\ &= 2\left[\frac{7}{36} + \frac{2}{9}\right] = 2\left[\frac{7}{36} + \frac{8}{36}\right] \\ &= 2 \cdot \frac{15}{36} = \frac{15}{18} = \frac{5}{6}. \end{aligned}P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3)​=2[∫x=1/22/3​∫y=1−x1​dydx+∫x=2/31​∫y=1/31​dydx]=2[∫1/22/3​(1−(1−x))dx+∫2/31​(1−1/3)dx]=2[∫1/22/3​xdx+∫2/31​32​dx]=2[2x2​​1/22/3​+32​(1−2/3)]=2[2(2/3)2−(1/2)2​+32​⋅31​]=2[294​−41​​+92​]=2[23616​−369​​+92​]=2[367​+92​]=2[367​+368​]=2⋅3615​=1815​=65​.​

    So P(X≥1/2P(X \ge 1/2P(X≥1/2 and Y>1/3)=5/6Y > 1/3) = 5/6Y>1/3)=5/6. Now divide by P(Y>1/3)=8/9P(Y>1/3) = 8/9P(Y>1/3)=8/9:

    P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3)=5689=56⋅98=5⋅96⋅8=4548=1516=0.9375.P(X \ge 1/2 \mid Y > 1/3) = \frac{\frac{5}{6}}{\frac{8}{9}} = \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{9}{8} = \frac{5 \cdot 9}{6 \cdot 8} = \frac{45}{48} = \frac{15}{16} = 0.9375. P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3)=98​65​​=65​⋅89​=6⋅85⋅9​=4845​=1615​=0.9375.

    Let’s double-check by another reasoning method (perhaps using the marginals/conditioning directly). Another approach: find the conditional density of XXX given Y>1/3Y>1/3Y>1/3. However, that might be a bit complicated to derive directly. Instead, confirm the joint area calculation by geometry: The event {X≥1/2,Y>1/3}\{X \ge 1/2, Y > 1/3\}{X≥1/2,Y>1/3} corresponds to the portion of the triangle SXYS_{XY}SXY​ that lies to the right of x=1/2x=1/2x=1/2 and above y=1/3y=1/3y=1/3. If we draw the triangle, x=1/2x=1/2x=1/2 is a vertical line halfway through, and y=1/3y=1/3y=1/3 is a horizontal line. The overlap of x≥0.5x \ge 0.5x≥0.5 and y>0.333y > 0.333y>0.333 inside the triangle is a smaller polygon. It might be tricky to compute area directly, but our integration seems right. (We can also integrate using the marginal of YYY and then conditional P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)P(X\ge1/2 \mid Y=y)P(X≥1/2∣Y=y), but that ultimately is similar steps.) Our answer 1516\frac{15}{16}1615​ is quite high, meaning given YYY is above 1/3, there’s a 93.75% chance X≥1/2X \ge 1/2X≥1/2. This seems plausible because when YYY is large (close to 1), XXX tends to be forced to also be large (since x≥1−yx \ge 1-yx≥1−y).

  • Shortcut-based solution: We can use the marginal densities and conditional probability formula more directly. We have P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3)=P(X≥1/2 and Y>1/3)P(Y>1/3)P(X \ge 1/2 \mid Y > 1/3) = \frac{P(X \ge 1/2 \text{ and } Y > 1/3)}{P(Y > 1/3)}P(X≥1/2∣Y>1/3)=P(Y>1/3)P(X≥1/2 and Y>1/3)​. We already found P(Y>1/3)=8/9P(Y>1/3) = 8/9P(Y>1/3)=8/9. Now let’s find P(X≥1/2 and Y>1/3)P(X \ge 1/2 \text{ and } Y > 1/3)P(X≥1/2 and Y>1/3) more cleverly. Instead of double integrating in x,yx,yx,y, consider complement approaches or symmetry. The entire triangle has area 0.50.50.5 (probability 1). We want the portion of that triangle that lies outside the region x<1/2x < 1/2x<1/2 or y≤1/3y \le 1/3y≤1/3. It might be easier to compute the complement: P([either X<1/2 or Y≤1/3])P(\text{[either }X < 1/2 \text{ or } Y \le 1/3])P([either X<1/2 or Y≤1/3]) and subtract from 1. But inclusion-exclusion would be needed if doing that. Perhaps easier: We can integrate using the marginal of YYY:

    P(X≥1/2, Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)fY(y) dy.P(X \ge 1/2,\, Y > 1/3) = \int_{y=1/3}^{1} P(X \ge 1/2 \mid Y=y) f_Y(y)\,dy. P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31​P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)fY​(y)dy.

    Given a particular yyy, what is P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)P(X \ge 1/2 \mid Y=y)P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)? Given Y=yY=yY=y, XXX is uniform from 000 to 1−y1-y1−y (because xxx goes from 0 up to 1−y1-y1−y on the support). So P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)=0P(X \ge 1/2 \mid Y=y) = 0P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)=0 if 1−y<1/21-y < 1/21−y<1/2 (i.e. if y>1/2y > 1/2y>1/2 then the entire allowed range of xxx is below 1/21/21/2 so it’s impossible for X≥1/2X \ge 1/2X≥1/2). If 1−y≥1/21-y \ge 1/21−y≥1/2 (i.e. y≤1/2y \le 1/2y≤1/2), then conditional on that yyy, the proportion of xxx values in [0,1−y][0,1-y][0,1−y] that satisfy x≥1/2x \ge 1/2x≥1/2 is (1−y)−(1/2)1−y=1−1/21−y\frac{(1-y) - (1/2)}{1-y} = 1 - \frac{1/2}{1-y}1−y(1−y)−(1/2)​=1−1−y1/2​ as long as 1/2≤1−y1/2 \le 1-y1/2≤1−y. Simplify: that is 1−y−1/21−y=1−1/21−y\frac{1-y - 1/2}{1-y} = 1 - \frac{1/2}{1-y}1−y1−y−1/2​=1−1−y1/2​. Actually, it might be simpler: for a given yyy, if y≤1/2y \le 1/2y≤1/2, then xxx can go up to 1−y≥1/21-y \ge 1/21−y≥1/2. The fraction of the xxx-interval [0,1−y][0,1-y][0,1−y] from x=1/2x=1/2x=1/2 to x=1−yx=1-yx=1−y is (1−y)−(1/2) 1−y \frac{(1-y) - (1/2)}{\,1-y\,}1−y(1−y)−(1/2)​ (when 1−y≥1/21-y \ge 1/21−y≥1/2). If y>1/2y > 1/2y>1/2, then P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)=0P(X\ge1/2|Y=y)=0P(X≥1/2∣Y=y)=0 because xxx only goes up to 1−y<1/21-y < 1/21−y<1/2. So we split at y=1/2y=1/2y=1/2:

    P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31/2(1−y)−1/2 1−y  fY(y) dy+∫y=1/210⋅fY(y) dy.P(X \ge 1/2, Y>1/3) = \int_{y=1/3}^{1/2} \frac{(1-y) - 1/2}{\,1-y\,} \,f_Y(y)\,dy + \int_{y=1/2}^{1} 0 \cdot f_Y(y)\,dy. P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31/2​1−y(1−y)−1/2​fY​(y)dy+∫y=1/21​0⋅fY​(y)dy.

    For y∈[1/3,1/2]y\in[1/3,1/2]y∈[1/3,1/2], this simplifies: (1−y)−1/21−y=1−y−1/21−y=1/2−y1−y\frac{(1-y) - 1/2}{1-y} = \frac{1 - y - 1/2}{1-y} = \frac{1/2 - y}{1-y}1−y(1−y)−1/2​=1−y1−y−1/2​=1−y1/2−y​. And fY(y)=2(1−y)f_Y(y) = 2(1-y)fY​(y)=2(1−y). So the integrand becomes 1/2−y1−y⋅2(1−y)=2(1/2−y)=1−2y\frac{1/2 - y}{1-y} \cdot 2(1-y) = 2(1/2 - y) = 1 - 2y1−y1/2−y​⋅2(1−y)=2(1/2−y)=1−2y. Thus:

    P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31/2(1−2y) dy.P(X \ge 1/2, Y>1/3) = \int_{y=1/3}^{1/2} (1 - 2y)\,dy. P(X≥1/2,Y>1/3)=∫y=1/31/2​(1−2y)dy.

    Now integrate: ∫(1−2y)dy=y−y2\int (1 - 2y)dy = y - y^2∫(1−2y)dy=y−y2. Evaluate from 1/31/31/3 to 1/21/21/2:

    Did we get 1/361/361/36? That seems to contradict the earlier 5/65/65/6 result — clearly something is off. Part 4: P(X+Y>1/2)P(X + Y > 1/2)P(X+Y>1/2) (Bonus)

Problem 3 📊

Given:

  • X1,X2,…,XnX_1, X_2, \ldots, X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​ are i.i.d. Exponential(λ)\text{Exponential}(\lambda)Exponential(λ) random variables (each with rate λ\lambdaλ).

Determine:

  1. The moment generating function MXˉn(t)M_{\bar{X}_n}(t)MXˉn​​(t) of the sample mean Xˉn=1n∑i=1nXi\displaystyle \bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_iXˉn​=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​.
  2. lim⁡n→∞MXˉn(t)\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} M_{\bar{X}_n}(t)n→∞lim​MXˉn​​(t).
  3. (Bonus) MY1(t)M_{Y_1}(t)MY1​​(t), where Y1=min⁡{X1,…,Xn}Y_1 = \min\{X_1,\ldots,X_n\}Y1​=min{X1​,…,Xn​} (the MGF of the minimum of the nnn samples).

Part 1: MXˉn(t)M_{\bar{X}_n}(t)MXˉn​​(t)

  • Derivation-based solution: The sample mean Xˉn=1n(X1+X2+⋯+Xn)\bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n}(X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n)Xˉn​=n1​(X1​+X2​+⋯+Xn​). We can find its MGF using the linearity inside the exponent. In general, if Z=aWZ = aWZ=aW for some constant aaa, then MZ(t)=E[et(aW)]=E[e(at)W]=MW(at)M_Z(t) = E[e^{t(aW)}] = E[e^{(at)W}] = M_W(at)MZ​(t)=E[et(aW)]=E[e(at)W]=MW​(at). Here, Xˉn=1n∑i=1nXi\bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_iXˉn​=n1​∑i=1n​Xi​. We can treat Sn=∑i=1nXiS_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_iSn​=∑i=1n​Xi​ first. Because the XiX_iXi​ are independent, the MGF of their sum is the product of individual MGFs:

    MSn(u)=MX1+⋯+Xn(u)=MX1(u)⋅MX2(u)⋯MXn(u).M_{S_n}(u) = M_{X_1 + \cdots + X_n}(u) = M_{X_1}(u) \cdot M_{X_2}(u) \cdots M_{X_n}(u). MSn​​(u)=MX1​+⋯+Xn​​(u)=MX1​​(u)⋅MX2​​(u)⋯MXn​​(u).

    Since each Xi∼Exp(λ)X_i \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)Xi​∼Exp(λ), we know from the refresher that MXi(u)=λλ−uM_{X_i}(u) = \frac{\lambda}{\lambda - u}MXi​​(u)=λ−uλ​ (valid for u<λu < \lambdau<λ). So,

    MSn(u)=(λλ−u)n,(u<λ).M_{S_n}(u) = \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - u}\right)^n, \qquad (u < \lambda). MSn​​(u)=(λ−uλ​)n,(u<λ).

    Now Xˉn=1nSn\bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n} S_nXˉn​=n1​Sn​. Using the linear scaling property: MXˉn(t)=MSn(t/n)M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = M_{S_n}(t/n)MXˉn​​(t)=MSn​​(t/n) (because etXˉn=et1nSn=e(t/n)Sne^{t \bar{X}_n} = e^{t \frac{1}{n}S_n} = e^{(t/n) S_n}etXˉn​=etn1​Sn​=e(t/n)Sn​). Therefore,

    MXˉn(t)=(λλ−tn)n,(t<nλ).M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - \frac{t}{n}}\right)^n, \qquad (t < n\lambda). MXˉn​​(t)=(λ−nt​λ​)n,(t<nλ).

    We can leave it in this form or simplify it slightly: λλ−tn=11−tλn\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - \frac{t}{n}} = \frac{1}{1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}}λ−nt​λ​=1−λnt​1​. So

    MXˉn(t)=(11−tλn)n=(1−tλn)−n.M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = \left(\frac{1}{1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}}\right)^n = \Big(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\Big)^{-n}. MXˉn​​(t)=(1−λnt​1​)n=(1−λnt​)−n.

    This is a nice form because it hints at a limit as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞. In summary,

    MXˉn(t)=(1−tλn)−n,for t<nλ.\displaystyle M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = \Big(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\Big)^{-n}, \quad \text{for } t < n\lambda. MXˉn​​(t)=(1−λnt​)−n,for t<nλ.

  • Shortcut-based solution: We can recall a known fact: the sum of nnn independent Exp(λ)\text{Exp}(\lambda)Exp(λ) is Gamma(n,λ)\text{Gamma}(n, \lambda)Gamma(n,λ). And the sample mean Xˉn=Sn/n\bar{X}_n = S_n/nXˉn​=Sn​/n is just a scaled Gamma. The MGF of a Gamma$(n,\lambda)$ (shape nnn, rate λ\lambdaλ) is (λ/(λ−t))n(\lambda/(\lambda - t))^n(λ/(λ−t))n. So MSn(t)=(λ/(λ−t))nM_{S_n}(t) = (\lambda/(\lambda - t))^nMSn​​(t)=(λ/(λ−t))n. Now replace ttt by t/nt/nt/n (because Xˉn=Sn/n\bar{X}_n = S_n/nXˉn​=Sn​/n):

    MXˉn(t)=(λλ−t/n)n.M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = \Big(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t/n}\Big)^n. MXˉn​​(t)=(λ−t/nλ​)n.

    This is the result with minimal fuss. It might also be recognized that Xˉn\bar{X}_nXˉn​ has the same distribution as 1λ1nχ2n2\frac{1}{\lambda} \frac{1}{n}\chi^2_{2n}λ1​n1​χ2n2​ (since a Gamma(n,λn,\lambdan,λ) is like χ2\chi^2χ2 with 2n2n2n degrees scaled appropriately), but that’s not needed for the MGF.

Part 2: lim⁡n→∞MXˉn(t)\lim_{n \to \infty} M_{\bar{X}_n}(t)limn→∞​MXˉn​​(t)

  • Derivation-based solution: We have MXˉn(t)=(1−tλn)−nM_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = \left(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\right)^{-n}MXˉn​​(t)=(1−λnt​)−n. We need lim⁡n→∞(1−tλn)−n\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\right)^{-n}limn→∞​(1−λnt​)−n. This is a classic limit that resembles the definition of the exponential function. Recall that lim⁡m→∞(1+am)m=ea\lim_{m\to\infty} (1 + \frac{a}{m})^m = e^{a}limm→∞​(1+ma​)m=ea. Here we have (1−tλn)−n(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n})^{-n}(1−λnt​)−n. Let’s put it in a similar form:

    (1−tλn)−n=[(1−tλn)−λnt]−tλ,(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n})^{-n} = \left[\Big(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\Big)^{-\frac{\lambda n}{t}}\right]^{-\frac{t}{\lambda}}, (1−λnt​)−n=[(1−λnt​)−tλn​]−λt​,

    which might be overkill. Instead, consider the natural log:

    ln⁡MXˉn(t)=−nln⁡(1−tλn).\ln M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = -n \ln\Big(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\Big). lnMXˉn​​(t)=−nln(1−λnt​).

    Using the approximation ln⁡(1+z)∼z\ln(1+z) \sim zln(1+z)∼z for small zzz, here z=−tλnz = -\frac{t}{\lambda n}z=−λnt​, for large nnn:

    ln⁡MXˉn(t)≈−n(−tλn−12(−tλn)2+⋯)=tλ+O(1/n).\ln M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) \approx -n\Big(-\frac{t}{\lambda n} - \frac{1}{2}\big(-\frac{t}{\lambda n}\big)^2 + \cdots\Big) = \frac{t}{\lambda} + O(1/n). lnMXˉn​​(t)≈−n(−λnt​−21​(−λnt​)2+⋯)=λt​+O(1/n).

    As n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, the higher order terms vanish, so ln⁡MXˉn(t)→tλ\ln M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) \to \frac{t}{\lambda}lnMXˉn​​(t)→λt​. Exponentiating,

    MXˉn(t)→e t/λ.M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) \to e^{\,t/\lambda}. MXˉn​​(t)→et/λ.

    This suggests that for large nnn, MXˉn(t)≈et/λM_{\bar{X}_n}(t) \approx e^{t/\lambda}MXˉn​​(t)≈et/λ. Notably, et/λe^{t/\lambda}et/λ is the MGF of a degenerate random variable at x=1/λx = 1/\lambdax=1/λ (since E[etX]=et⋅1/λE[e^{tX}] = e^{t\cdot 1/\lambda}E[etX]=et⋅1/λ would imply XXX is constantly 1/λ1/\lambda1/λ). This makes sense, because by the Law of Large Numbers, Xˉn\bar{X}_nXˉn​ converges (in probability) to the true mean 1/λ1/\lambda1/λ. So in the limit, Xˉn\bar{X}_nXˉn​ behaves like the constant 1/λ1/\lambda1/λ. In other words,

    lim⁡n→∞MXˉn(t)=e t/λ.\lim_{n \to \infty} M_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = e^{\,t/\lambda}. n→∞lim​MXˉn​​(t)=et/λ.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Starting from MXˉn(t)=(1−tλn)−nM_{\bar{X}_n}(t) = \left(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\right)^{-n}MXˉn​​(t)=(1−λnt​)−n, recognize the limit form: lim⁡n→∞(1−tλn)−n=exp⁡ ⁣{lim⁡n→∞−nln⁡(1−tλn)}\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\right)^{-n} = \exp\!\{\lim_{n\to\infty} -n \ln(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n})\}limn→∞​(1−λnt​)−n=exp{limn→∞​−nln(1−λnt​)}. Now lim⁡n→∞−nln⁡(1−tλn)\lim_{n\to\infty} -n \ln(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n})limn→∞​−nln(1−λnt​) can be found by L’Hôpital’s rule treating it as −ln⁡(1−tλn)1/n\frac{-\ln(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n})}{1/n}1/n−ln(1−λnt​)​. But it’s quicker to recall the standard limit lim⁡m→∞(1+am)m=ea\lim_{m \to \infty}(1 + \frac{a}{m})^m = e^{a}limm→∞​(1+ma​)m=ea. Here we have a minus sign, but we can fit it in the formula by setting a=−t/λa = -t/\lambdaa=−t/λ and m=nm = nm=n:

    lim⁡n→∞(1+−t/λn)n=e−t/λ.\lim_{n\to\infty}\Big(1 + \frac{-t/\lambda}{n}\Big)^n = e^{-t/\lambda}. n→∞lim​(1+n−t/λ​)n=e−t/λ.

    However, our expression is (1−tλn)−n=[(1−tλn)n]−1(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n})^{-n} = \Big[\big(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\big)^n\Big]^{-1}(1−λnt​)−n=[(1−λnt​)n]−1. And lim⁡n→∞(1−tλn)n=e−t/λ\lim_{n\to\infty}\big(1 - \frac{t}{\lambda n}\big)^n = e^{-t/\lambda}limn→∞​(1−λnt​)n=e−t/λ. So its reciprocal is et/λe^{t/\lambda}et/λ. Thus the answer is et/λe^{t/\lambda}et/λ.

Part 3: MY1(t)M_{Y_1}(t)MY1​​(t) for Y1=min⁡{X1,…,Xn}Y_1 = \min\{X_1,\ldots,X_n\}Y1​=min{X1​,…,Xn​} (Bonus)

  • Derivation-based solution: The minimum of nnn i.i.d. exponentials has a well-known distribution. Another approach is to derive its MGF from first principles. We know Y1=min⁡(X1,…,Xn)Y_1 = \min(X_1,\ldots,X_n)Y1​=min(X1​,…,Xn​). We can use the CDF method or Law of the unconscious statistician:

    MY1(t)=E[etY1]=∫0∞etyfY1(y) dy.M_{Y_1}(t) = E[e^{t Y_1}] = \int_0^\infty e^{t y} f_{Y_1}(y)\,dy. MY1​​(t)=E[etY1​]=∫0∞​etyfY1​​(y)dy.

    But finding fY1(y)f_{Y_1}(y)fY1​​(y) first might be easier: The CDF of the minimum is FY1(y)=1−P(Y1>y)=1−P(X1>y,…,Xn>y)F_{Y_1}(y) = 1 - P(Y_1 > y) = 1 - P(X_1 > y, \ldots, X_n > y)FY1​​(y)=1−P(Y1​>y)=1−P(X1​>y,…,Xn​>y). For independent exponentials, P(Xi>y)=e−λyP(X_i > y) = e^{-\lambda y}P(Xi​>y)=e−λy. So

    P(Y1>y)=P(X1>y)n=e−nλy.P(Y_1 > y) = P(X_1 > y)^n = e^{-n\lambda y}. P(Y1​>y)=P(X1​>y)n=e−nλy.

    Thus FY1(y)=1−e−nλyF_{Y_1}(y) = 1 - e^{-n\lambda y}FY1​​(y)=1−e−nλy. This is exactly the CDF of an Exp(nλ)\text{Exp}(n\lambda)Exp(nλ) distribution. Differentiating, fY1(y)=nλe−nλyf_{Y_1}(y) = n\lambda e^{-n\lambda y}fY1​​(y)=nλe−nλy for y≥0y \ge 0y≥0. Now we can find the MGF by integration:

    MY1(t)=∫0∞ety(nλ)e−nλy dy=nλ∫0∞e−(nλ−t)y dy,M_{Y_1}(t) = \int_0^\infty e^{t y} (n\lambda) e^{-n\lambda y}\,dy = n\lambda \int_0^\infty e^{-(n\lambda - t)y}\,dy, MY1​​(t)=∫0∞​ety(nλ)e−nλydy=nλ∫0∞​e−(nλ−t)ydy,

    which converges for t<nλt < n\lambdat<nλ. Evaluating the integral:

    ∫0∞e−(nλ−t)y dy=1 nλ−t ,for t<nλ.\int_0^\infty e^{- (n\lambda - t) y}\,dy = \frac{1}{\,n\lambda - t\,}, \qquad \text{for } t < n\lambda. ∫0∞​e−(nλ−t)ydy=nλ−t1​,for t<nλ.

    Multiply by nλn\lambdanλ:

    MY1(t)=nλ nλ−t ,(t<nλ).M_{Y_1}(t) = \frac{n\lambda}{\,n\lambda - t\,}, \quad (t < n\lambda). MY1​​(t)=nλ−tnλ​,(t<nλ).

    This is the MGF of an Exp(nλ)\text{Exp}(n\lambda)Exp(nλ) random variable, which is consistent with our identification of the distribution.

  • Shortcut-based solution: We can avoid integration by using knowledge of MGFs and independence. There’s a general result: for nonnegative independent random variables, the MGF of the minimum can be found by using P(Y1>y)P(Y_1 > y)P(Y1​>y) as above or using the survival function approach directly in the MGF:

    MY1(t)=E[etmin⁡iXi]=E[max⁡ietXi]M_{Y_1}(t) = E[e^{t \min_i X_i}] = E[\max_i e^{t X_i}] MY1​​(t)=E[etmini​Xi​]=E[imax​etXi​]

    (since etmin⁡X=max⁡etXe^{t \min X} = \max e^{tX}etminX=maxetX). However, that route is a bit complicated. Instead, rely on the known fact: min⁡{X1,…,Xn}∼Exp(nλ)\min\{X_1,\dots,X_n\} \sim \text{Exp}(n\lambda)min{X1​,…,Xn​}∼Exp(nλ) when Xi∼Exp(λ)X_i \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)Xi​∼Exp(λ) i.i.d. Intuitively, having nnn independent "channels" for an exponential event speeds up the rate by factor nnn. Thus by inspection, the MGF should be nλnλ−t\frac{n\lambda}{n\lambda - t}nλ−tnλ​ (for t<nλt < n\lambdat<nλ), since that is the MGF of Exp$(n\lambda)$. This matches the derived result.

Problem 4 📈

Given:

  • X1,X2,…,XnX_1, X_2, \ldots, X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​ are i.i.d. Beta(1,1)\text{Beta}(1,1)Beta(1,1) random variables on [0,1][0,1][0,1]. (Note: Beta(1,1)\text{Beta}(1,1)Beta(1,1) is just a uniform distribution on [0,1].)
  • Let Y(1)≤Y(2)≤⋯≤Y(n)Y_{(1)} \le Y_{(2)} \le \cdots \le Y_{(n)}Y(1)​≤Y(2)​≤⋯≤Y(n)​ be the order statistics of the sample (i.e. Y(i)Y_{(i)}Y(i)​ is the $i$th smallest of the XjX_jXj​’s). We are told n≥4n \ge 4n≥4 (so that Y(4)Y_{(4)}Y(4)​ is well-defined as the 4th order stat).

Determine:

  1. P(X4>3/4)P(X_4 > 3/4)P(X4​>3/4).
  2. P(Y4>3/4)P(Y_4 > 3/4)P(Y4​>3/4).
  3. (Bonus) The joint density fYi,Yj,Yk(yi,yj,yk)f_{Y_i,Y_j,Y_k}(y_i, y_j, y_k)fYi​,Yj​,Yk​​(yi​,yj​,yk​) for any 1≤i<j<k≤n1 \le i < j < k \le n1≤i<j<k≤n.

First, note that since each XiX_iXi​ is Uniform(0,1)\text{Uniform}(0,1)Uniform(0,1), their joint distribution is symmetric on the unit cube [0,1]n[0,1]^n[0,1]n. The order statistics Y(i)Y_{(i)}Y(i)​ themselves have known distributions related to the Beta distribution. We’ll approach each part carefully:

Part 1: P(X4>3/4)P(X_4 > 3/4)P(X4​>3/4)

  • Derivation-based solution: Here X4X_4X4​ refers to the fourth random variable (not the 4th smallest, but the one labeled with index 4). Since all XiX_iXi​ are i.i.d. U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), X4X_4X4​ is just U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1) as well. The probability that a uniform(0,1) exceeds 3/43/43/4 is simply the length of the interval (3/4,1](3/4, 1](3/4,1]:

    P(X4>3/4)=1−P(X4≤3/4)=1−3/4−01−0=1−34=14=0.25.P(X_4 > 3/4) = 1 - P(X_4 \le 3/4) = 1 - \frac{3/4 - 0}{1 - 0} = 1 - \frac{3}{4} = \frac{1}{4} = 0.25. P(X4​>3/4)=1−P(X4​≤3/4)=1−1−03/4−0​=1−43​=41​=0.25.

    It’s straightforward because for a uniform distribution, probabilities correspond to interval lengths.

  • Shortcut-based solution: No need for heavy calculation: by symmetry each XiX_iXi​ is uniform on [0,1], so P(X4>0.75)=0.25P(X_4 > 0.75) = 0.25P(X4​>0.75)=0.25. (Alternatively, one could note X4X_4X4​ has CDF F(x)=xF(x)=xF(x)=x on [0,1], so plug x=0.75x=0.75x=0.75: P(X4≤0.75)=0.75P(X_4 \le 0.75) = 0.75P(X4​≤0.75)=0.75, hence the complement is 0.250.250.25.)

Part 2: P(Y4>3/4)P(Y_4 > 3/4)P(Y4​>3/4)

  • Derivation-based solution: Now Y4Y_4Y4​ is the 4th order statistic (the 4th smallest out of the nnn samples). We need the probability that this 4th smallest value is greater than 0.75. In other words, we want the event that at least 4 samples are above 0.75 (because if the 4th smallest is above 0.75, it means even the fourth one from the bottom is > 0.75, so at most 3 samples could be ≤0.75\le 0.75≤0.75). It might be easier to use complementary thinking or a known formula for order stats:

    Method 1: Complementary counting:
    P(Y4>0.75)=1−P(Y4≤0.75)P(Y_4 > 0.75) = 1 - P(Y_4 \le 0.75)P(Y4​>0.75)=1−P(Y4​≤0.75). Now Y4≤0.75Y_4 \le 0.75Y4​≤0.75 means the 4th smallest is at most 0.75. That implies at least 4 of the samples are ≤0.75\le 0.75≤0.75. (If fewer than 4 samples were ≤0.75\le 0.75≤0.75, then the 4th smallest would be above 0.75. So “Y4≤0.75Y_4 \le 0.75Y4​≤0.75” is equivalent to “$#samplessamples samples\le 0.75 \ge 4$”.) We can model the number of samples ≤0.75\le 0.75≤0.75 as a Binomial$(n, 0.75),sinceeachsampleindependentlyhasa75, since each sample independently has a 75% chance to fall in ,sinceeachsampleindependentlyhasa75[0,0.75]$. Let K=#{i:Xi≤0.75}K = \#\{i: X_i \le 0.75\}K=#{i:Xi​≤0.75}. Then:

    P(Y4≤0.75)=P(K≥4)=∑k=4n(nk)(0.75)k(0.25) n−k.P(Y_4 \le 0.75) = P(K \ge 4) = \sum_{k=4}^{n} \binom{n}{k} (0.75)^k (0.25)^{\,n-k}. P(Y4​≤0.75)=P(K≥4)=k=4∑n​(kn​)(0.75)k(0.25)n−k.

    This sum computes the probability that 4 or more of the XiX_iXi​’s lie in [0,0.75][0,0.75][0,0.75]. Therefore,

    P(Y4>0.75)=1−∑k=4n(nk)(0.75)k(0.25) n−k=∑k=03(nk)(0.75)k(0.25) n−k.P(Y_4 > 0.75) = 1 - \sum_{k=4}^{n} \binom{n}{k} (0.75)^k (0.25)^{\,n-k} = \sum_{k=0}^{3} \binom{n}{k} (0.75)^k (0.25)^{\,n-k}. P(Y4​>0.75)=1−k=4∑n​(kn​)(0.75)k(0.25)n−k=k=0∑3​(kn​)(0.75)k(0.25)n−k.

    (We used the fact that the total sum of probabilities from k=0k=0k=0 to nnn equals 1, to rewrite the complement as the sum from k=0k=0k=0 to 333.) This expression is perfectly valid. If we want a simplified closed form, it’s essentially the CDF of Binomial$(n,0.75)$ at k=3k=3k=3. There isn’t a simpler closed form unless we plug in an nnn or leave it as is.

    Method 2: Beta distribution of order statistic:
    Since the XiX_iXi​ are i.i.d. U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), Y(4)Y_{(4)}Y(4)​ (the 4th smallest) has a Beta(4,  n−4+1)\text{Beta}(4,\; n-4+1)Beta(4,n−4+1) distribution, i.e. Beta(4, n−3)\text{Beta}(4,\, n-3)Beta(4,n−3). (In general Y(k)∼Beta(k,  n−k+1)Y_{(k)} \sim \text{Beta}(k,\; n-k+1)Y(k)​∼Beta(k,n−k+1).) We could use this fact to get P(Y4>0.75)P(Y_4 > 0.75)P(Y4​>0.75) by integrating the Beta tail from 0.75 to 1. The CDF of a Beta is given by the incomplete beta function. Using that:

    P(Y4>0.75)=I0.75(4, n−3)c=1−I0.75(4,  n−3),P(Y_4 > 0.75) = I_{0.75}(4,\,n-3)^c = 1 - I_{0.75}(4,\; n-3), P(Y4​>0.75)=I0.75​(4,n−3)c=1−I0.75​(4,n−3),

    where Ix(a,b)I_x(a,b)Ix​(a,b) is the regularized incomplete beta. But let’s avoid that complexity. The binomial method above is actually simpler in practice. If needed for specific nnn, one could plug values. For instance, if n=4n=4n=4 exactly, then P(Y4>0.75)=P(max⁡{Xi}>0.75)=1−P(all Xi≤0.75)=1−(0.75)4=1−0.3164=0.6836P(Y_4 > 0.75) = P(\max\{X_i\} > 0.75) = 1 - P(\text{all } X_i \le 0.75) = 1 - (0.75)^4 = 1 - 0.3164 = 0.6836P(Y4​>0.75)=P(max{Xi​}>0.75)=1−P(all Xi​≤0.75)=1−(0.75)4=1−0.3164=0.6836. If n=5n=5n=5, P(Y4>0.75)=∑k=03(5k)(0.75)k(0.25)5−kP(Y_4 > 0.75) = \sum_{k=0}^{3} \binom{5}{k} (0.75)^k (0.25)^{5-k}P(Y4​>0.75)=∑k=03​(k5​)(0.75)k(0.25)5−k. In general, leaving the answer in summation form is acceptable.

  • Shortcut-based solution: The reasoning about “at least 4 samples above 0.75” can be done more directly: for Y4Y_4Y4​ to exceed 0.75, at most 3 samples can be ≤0.75\le 0.75≤0.75 (equivalently, at least (n−3)(n-3)(n−3) samples are >0.75>0.75>0.75). Another way: P(Y4>0.75)=P(at least 4 of the Xi>0.75)P(Y_4 > 0.75) = P(\text{at least 4 of the }X_i > 0.75)P(Y4​>0.75)=P(at least 4 of the Xi​>0.75). Each XiX_iXi​ has probability 0.250.250.25 to be >0.75>0.75>0.75. So let K′=#{i:Xi>0.75}K' = \#\{i: X_i > 0.75\}K′=#{i:Xi​>0.75}. Then K′∼Bin(n,0.25)K' \sim \text{Bin}(n, 0.25)K′∼Bin(n,0.25) and

    P(Y4>0.75)=P(K′≥4)=∑j=4n(nj)(0.25)j(0.75) n−j.P(Y_4 > 0.75) = P(K' \ge 4) = \sum_{j=4}^{n} \binom{n}{j} (0.25)^j (0.75)^{\,n-j}. P(Y4​>0.75)=P(K′≥4)=j=4∑n​(jn​)(0.25)j(0.75)n−j.

    This is of course algebraically the same as the previous result (just indexing with j=n−kj = n-kj=n−k essentially). If nnn is large or unspecified, giving the answer as a summation or using the binomial CDF is fine. If needed, one can compute numeric values for given nnn.

Part 3: Joint density fYi,Yj,Yk(yi,yj,yk)f_{Y_i,Y_j,Y_k}(y_i, y_j, y_k)fYi​,Yj​,Yk​​(yi​,yj​,yk​) (Bonus)

  • Derivation-based solution: The joint PDF of multiple order statistics can be derived from the symmetric joint density of the original sample. In general, if 1≤i<j<k≤n1 \le i < j < k \le n1≤i<j<k≤n, the joint density for Y(i),Y(j),Y(k)Y_{(i)}, Y_{(j)}, Y_{(k)}Y(i)​,Y(j)​,Y(k)​ (the $i$th, $j$th, and $k$th order stats) is:

    fY(i), Y(j), Y(k)(yi,yj,yk)=n!(i−1)! (j−i−1)! (k−j−1)! (n−k)!×[fX(yi)] [fX(yj)] [fX(yk)]×[FX(yi)] i−1  [FX(yj)−FX(yi)]  j−i−1×[FX(yk)−FX(yj)]  k−j−1  [1−FX(yk)] n−k,\begin{aligned} f_{Y_{(i)},\,Y_{(j)},\,Y_{(k)}}(y_i, y_j, y_k) &= \frac{n!}{(i-1)!\, (j-i-1)!\, (k-j-1)!\, (n-k)!} \\ &\quad \times [f_X(y_i)]\,[f_X(y_j)]\,[f_X(y_k)] \\ &\quad \times [F_X(y_i)]^{\,i-1}\;[F_X(y_j) - F_X(y_i)]^{\,\,j-i-1} \\ &\quad \times [F_X(y_k) - F_X(y_j)]^{\,\,k-j-1}\;[1 - F_X(y_k)]^{\,n-k}, \end{aligned}fY(i)​,Y(j)​,Y(k)​​(yi​,yj​,yk​)​=(i−1)!(j−i−1)!(k−j−1)!(n−k)!n!​×[fX​(yi​)][fX​(yj​)][fX​(yk​)]×[FX​(yi​)]i−1[FX​(yj​)−FX​(yi​)]j−i−1×[FX​(yk​)−FX​(yj​)]k−j−1[1−FX​(yk​)]n−k,​

    valid for 0≤yi≤yj≤yk≤10 \le y_i \le y_j \le y_k \le 10≤yi​≤yj​≤yk​≤1. This formula comes from: choosing which i−1i-1i−1 samples fall below yiy_iyi​, which j−i−1j-i-1j−i−1 fall between yiy_iyi​ and yjy_jyj​, which k−j−1k-j-1k−j−1 fall between yjy_jyj​ and yky_kyk​, and which n−kn-kn−k fall above yky_kyk​, then multiplying by the PDF factors for yi,yj,yky_i, y_j, y_kyi​,yj​,yk​.

    Now, for our specific case XXX is uniform(0,1). So fX(x)=1f_X(x) = 1fX​(x)=1 on [0,1][0,1][0,1], and FX(x)=xF_X(x) = xFX​(x)=x on [0,1][0,1][0,1]. Substituting these in simplifies the formula greatly (all fX(y∗)f_X(y_*)fX​(y∗​) terms become 1, and FX(y)=yF_X(y) = yFX​(y)=y):

    fY(i), Y(j), Y(k)(yi,yj,yk)=n!(i−1)! (j−i−1)! (k−j−1)! (n−k)!×[yi] i−1  [yj−yi]  j−i−1  [yk−yj]  k−j−1  [1−yk] n−k,\begin{aligned} f_{Y_{(i)},\,Y_{(j)},\,Y_{(k)}}(y_i, y_j, y_k) &= \frac{n!}{(i-1)!\,(j-i-1)!\,(k-j-1)!\,(n-k)!} \\ &\quad \times [y_i]^{\,i-1}\;[y_j - y_i]^{\,\,j-i-1}\;[y_k - y_j]^{\,\,k-j-1}\;[1 - y_k]^{\,n-k}, \end{aligned}fY(i)​,Y(j)​,Y(k)​​(yi​,yj​,yk​)​=(i−1)!(j−i−1)!(k−j−1)!(n−k)!n!​×[yi​]i−1[yj​−yi​]j−i−1[yk​−yj​]k−j−1[1−yk​]n−k,​

    for 0≤yi≤yj≤yk≤10 \le y_i \le y_j \le y_k \le 10≤yi​≤yj​≤yk​≤1. This is the joint PDF of the $i$th, $j$th, and $k$th order statistics of a sample of size nnn from Uniform(0,1)\text{Uniform}(0,1)Uniform(0,1).

    It’s worth noting that this is essentially a Dirichlet distribution form (the joint distribution of multiple order stats from uniform is related to sorted uniform spacings). If we were to integrate this over appropriate ranges we could derive marginal distributions or other properties. But as the final answer, the above formula is the most explicit form of the joint density.

  • Shortcut-based solution: One could recall that the vector of order statistics (Y(1),…,Y(n))(Y_{(1)},\dots,Y_{(n)})(Y(1)​,…,Y(n)​) for uniform samples has a Dirichlet distribution for the spacings: specifically, the gaps Y(1)−0Y_{(1)} - 0Y(1)​−0, Y(2)−Y(1)Y_{(2)}-Y_{(1)}Y(2)​−Y(1)​, ..., Y(n)−Y(n−1)Y_{(n)}-Y_{(n-1)}Y(n)​−Y(n−1)​, 1−Y(n)1 - Y_{(n)}1−Y(n)​ are independent Beta(1,n)\text{Beta}(1, n)Beta(1,n) etc. But it's easier to just remember the general formula for joint order stat density (as given above). Plugging fX(x)=1f_X(x)=1fX​(x)=1 and FX(x)=xF_X(x)=xFX​(x)=x yields the simplified result quickly. The key is the multinomial coefficient n!/((i−1)!(j−i−1)!(k−j−1)!(n−k)!)n!/( (i-1)!(j-i-1)!(k-j-1)!(n-k)! )n!/((i−1)!(j−i−1)!(k−j−1)!(n−k)!) and the respective powers of CDF segments. This captures that out of nnn points, i−1i-1i−1 are below yiy_iyi​, j−i−1j-i-1j−i−1 are between yiy_iyi​ and yjy_jyj​, etc. The final answer is the same as derived.
